author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Montana Derailment Sends 10 Freight Cars Into the Yellowstone River
description: Cars carrying molten sulfur or asphalt plunged into the river after a Montana Rail Link train derailed and a bridge collapsed on Saturday, officials said.
content: Ten cars from a freight train plunged into the Yellowstone River in Montana on Saturday after a derailment and a bridge collapse, causing asphalt and molten sulfur cargo to spill into the water, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Lakin
title: A Séance With Ryuichi Sakamoto at the Shed
description: “Kagami,” a new mixed-reality presentation, features a virtual likeness of the late composer. It becomes, mostly despite itself, an affecting meditation on grief.
content: “Kagami,” the new “mixed reality” concert of Ryuichi Sakamoto’s music by the production company Tin Drum is meant to be a profound experience, a groundbreaking achievement in virtual reality that expands the visual limits of recorded performance. In practice, it feels like a wake in a laser tag arena. In some ways that’s unavoidable; Sakamoto, one of Japan’s most internationally recognized artists, died in March, so any presentation of his music so soon is hard pressed to avoid a funereal pallor. This one doesn’t escape that fate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: One Big Winner of Kremlin-Wagner Clash? The Dictator Next Door.
description: The strongman leader of Belarus, a dependable ally of Vladimir Putin’s, may see a chance to rebrand himself as a statesman.
content: Vladimir V. Putin is known for his tight control over the news media in Russia. His onetime ally, the Wagner military group founder Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, is himself the owner of a conservative media outlet and a flamboyant showman on social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: How a Recycling Leader Spends His Sundays
description: Ryan Castalia, the head of the nonprofit “Sure We Can,” is also part of an experimental theater group.
content: In 2018, Ryan Castalia was juggling jobs to support his acting habit when he started working at Sure We Can, a recycling and sustainability hub in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Two years later, he was named the executive director of the nonprofit, which also provides support for canners, or those who collect recyclables for a living.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lia Picard
title: Barbiecore Is Surging Its Way into Home Décor and Interior Design
description: The upcoming movie and maximalism have sparked a palette made up primarily of hot pink.
content: Amanda Hansen loves a hot pink moment. “I think I just naturally am such a pink froufrou girl. All my stuff. Everything I buy is always a little bit Barbie-esque,” she said. “So it has taken over.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Michael Luttig
title: It’s Not Too Late for the Republican Party
description: The G.O.P. needs to have the reckoning with Trump that it vainly hoped would never be necessary.
content: Donald Trump this month became the first former or incumbent American president to be charged with crimes against the nation that he once led and wishes to lead again. He cynically calculated that his indictment would ensure that a riled-up Republican Party base would nominate him as its standard-bearer in 2024, and the last few weeks have proved that his political calculation was probably right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu and Steven Lee Myers
title: A.I.’s Use in Elections Sets Off a Scramble for Guardrails
description: Gaps in campaign rules allow politicians to spread images and messaging generated by increasingly powerful artificial intelligence technology.
content: In Toronto, a candidate in this week’s mayoral election who vows to clear homeless encampments released a set of campaign promises illustrated by artificial intelligence, including fake dystopian images of people camped out on a downtown street and a fabricated image of tents set up in a park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy and Kelley Manley
title: After the Club Q Shooting, Questions of Money and Justice for Victims
description: Just before they are set to face the accused shooter in court, some survivors of the Colorado mass shooting are frustrated over payouts from a fund to help them.
content: Ashtin Gamblin never realized how expensive it would be to survive a mass shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: ‘Twilight Zone: The Movie’ and the Deadly Accident That Plagued It
description: It’s been 40 years since the release of the film, but questions of what risks are permissible in the making of art have persisted.
content: When the anthology film “Twilight Zone: The Movie” opened on June 24, 1983, reviews were mixed; The New York Times’s Vincent Canby deemed it “a flabby, mini-minded behemoth,” and that was a fairly representative view. A middling box office performer, the film may well have been forgotten entirely were it not for another news event, related to the picture, reported that same day: the unsealing of the grand jury indictments against five of the filmmakers, including the director John Landis, for their responsibility in a stunt gone horrifyingly awry, killing three people during the picture’s production.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Polgreen
title: Death and Displacement Return to Darfur
description: The violent conflict in Sudan is expanding quickly.
content: ADRE, Chad — The janjaweed are back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler and Mark Abramson
title: A Vast Lake Has Captivated California Where Farms Stood a Year Ago
description: Tulare Lake re-emerged after intense storms battered the state this winter, and will likely remain in the Central Valley for months — and maybe years — to come.
content: It sounds like the sea and approaches the size of Lake Tahoe. Its wind-driven waves are unexpectedly silky and warm. Tulare Lake seems to go on forever on the immense brown and green flat of California’s Central Valley, shimmering like a great blue mirage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Oung
title: Just Made a Queer Memory? Drop a Pin.
description: Queering the Map, a crowdsourced digital atlas, has collected over half a million intimate recollections from anonymous contributors.
content: Name an L.G.B.T.Q. landmark. Perhaps it’s the Stonewall Inn on Christopher Street in Manhattan. Maybe it’s Castro Camera, Harvey Milk’s shop in San Francisco, or even the Coral Sea Islands, where activists started their own micronation to advocate the legalization of gay marriage in Australia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Putin’s Beast That Would Now Devour Him
description: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the founder of the paramilitary Wagner Group, has been driven to fury by a mismanaged war in Ukraine. He turned on his creator, before apparently reversing course.
content: Over the course of a month I spent in the Russian capital, the red-and-black billboards of Yevgeny V. Prigozhin’s Wagner paramilitary group multiplied. “Join the team of victors!” they said, beneath an image of menacing mercenaries in balaclavas and masks, only their eyes visible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: In Pitch to Evangelicals, Trump Casts Himself as Christian Crusader Who Helped End Roe v. Wade
description: Former President Donald J. Trump told an evangelical gathering that no president had done more for Christians than he did.
content: One year after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, former President Donald J. Trump reminded a gathering of evangelical activists in the nation’s capital how he had shaped the court’s conservative supermajority that ended nearly 50 years of constitutional protections for abortion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Fish Tacos al Pastor, Stained Delicious With a Complex, Brick-Red Adobo
description: Serve with a pineapple pico de gallo and plenty of warm corn tortillas.
content: Good morning. One of the great joys of being a reporter for the Food section of The New York Times is the chance to go into restaurant kitchens to learn how a chef prepares a dish you love, and then figure out how to make that same dish at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack and Michael Wilson
title: Dancing, Jubilation, and Worries About L.G.B.T.Q. Rights at Pride March
description: Support for L.G.B.T.Q. people has risen, but so have attacks against them, even in a city known for the strength of its community.
content: An unbroken parade of marchers — some dancing and jubilant, some set with determined purpose — filled Fifth Avenue and the streets of Greenwich Village in Manhattan on Sunday for the New York City Pride March, even as a foreboding backdrop from threats both local and national hung over the day’s slate of events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Philip Schuyler Is Knocked Off His Pedestal in Albany
description: A statue of the Revolutionary War general, newly prominent thanks to the musical “Hamilton,” has been removed from its place outside Albany City Hall because he enslaved people.
content: There was a time when one probably had to be a committed Revolutionary War buff or an aficionado of early Albany aristocracy to know the name Philip J. Schuyler.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: At 80, Meredith Monk Is Still Seeking Ways to Communicate
description: The staged premiere of her new work “Indra’s Net” in Amsterdam comes as a set of recordings offers a retrospective of one of our most humane artists.
content: Meredith Monk stepped out onto a circular stage, her stride paced yet fluid. She wore an all-white costume that seemed to belong to neither time nor place, and her signature braids, flowing from a neat part at the top of her head, bounced lightly over her shoulders. She didn’t sing at first, but when she did, she let out a clear, clean soprano sound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: Can Everyone Take a Sabbatical?
description: We all need a rest.
content: Olatunde Sobomehin, the chief executive and co-founder of StreetCode Academy, a Silicon Valley-based nonprofit that offers free tech classes to people from communities of color, thought that taking a sabbatical would be impossible. But his thinking began to change as he read and learned more about the practice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Morgan
title: As a Gay Man, I’ll Never Be Normal
description: As a closeted teen, I prayed fervently to be normal. What I was really praying for is comfort.
content: LGBT folks have a peculiar interest in normalization. Normalize men in dresses. Normalize trans athletes. Normalize throuples. Normalize fetishes. Here a norm, there a norm, everywhere a norm norm. Every norm everywhere all at once.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Human Remains Found in Area Where Actor Julian Sands Went Missing
description: Mr. Sands, 65, was reported missing in January after he went hiking alone on a trail on Mount Baldy in Southern California.
content: The authorities in Southern California recovered human remains on Saturday near the mountain where search crews have been looking for the British actor Julian Sands, who was reported missing in January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Gripped by Uncertainty After Mutiny, Russians Note Absence of Kremlin Leaders
description: Neither Vladimir V. Putin nor the leader of the Wagner mercenary group made public appearances on Sunday, a day after an armed rebellion shook the nation.
content: Confusion and uncertainty pervaded Russia on Sunday, with neither President Vladimir V. Putin nor Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the head of a mutinous mercenary group, appearing anywhere in public a day after the most profound government crisis in three decades — an open military rebellion — appeared defused.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: The Legal Foundation of Women’s Sports Is Under Fire
description: Evidence is overwhelming that there is a significant average difference between male and female athletic performance.
content: What is the legal foundation for women’s sports? It’s a simple question with a surprisingly complex answer. After all, the most potent federal statute supporting parallel men’s and women’s sports leagues would appear — on its face — to also prohibit separate leagues. Title IX of the Educational Amendments of 1972 states, “No person in the United States shall, on the basis of sex, be excluded from participation in, be denied the benefits of, or be subjected to discrimination under any education program or activity receiving federal financial assistance.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Dunlap
title: A Badge of Solidarity
description: The U.S. government named 22 defendants in its suit to stop The Times from publishing the Pentagon Papers. Two Times journalists designed a way to show support for their colleagues.
content: Vietnam War protesters whose tactics made them the target of government prosecution won notoriety in the 1960s and ’70s under collective designations like the Chicago Seven, the Harrisburg Seven and the Catonsville Nine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Crisis Abated
description: Vladimir Putin averted a threat that came closer than anything else has to endangering his hold on power.
content: Vladimir Putin has apparently survived the boldest challenge to his 23-year autocratic rule in Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Little Bitty
description: Delight in this choice puzzle by Taylor Johnson and Christina Iverson.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues | Solving Tip
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: How to Build a Scent Smorgasbord for Mosquitoes
description: To study how the African malaria mosquito homes in on its human targets, researchers built an enormous “flight cage.” in rural Zambia.
content: For a bloodthirsty, global health threat, the African malaria mosquito, Anopheles gambiae, has surprisingly discriminating taste. It prefers feeding on humans to other animals, is more attracted to some people than others and even then appears to have a particular predilection for feet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mariah Kreutter
title: Your Monday Briefing: The Aftermath of a Russian Revolt
description: Also, a gunpowder shipment from China and a #MeToo wave in Taiwan.
content: The day after an armed rebellion by Wagner mercenaries against Vladimir Putin’s government was defused at the last minute, neither Putin nor the mercenary leader, Yevgeny Prigozhin, made a public appearance, adding to the sense of uncertainty and confusion pervading Russia. The swirl of events over the last few days has left questions about Putin’s authority and the future of the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: With Wagner’s Future in Doubt, Ukraine Could Capitalize on Chaos
description: The group played an outsize role in the campaign to take Bakhmut, Moscow’s one major battlefield victory this year. The loss of the mercenary army could hurt Russia’s ambitions in the Ukraine war.
content: To some Ukrainian forces, soldiers from the Wagner Group were the best-equipped fighters they had seen since Russia invaded last year. To others, it was their training that distinguished them: Ukrainian soldiers recalled battlefield stories of aggressive tactics or a sniper downing a drone with a single shot.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: H. Lee Sarokin, 94, Judge Who Freed ‘Hurricane’ Carter, Is Dead
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 25, 2023.
content: “If we wish to shield our eyes and noses from the homeless, we should revoke their condition, not their library cards.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: Overlooked No More: Dolores Alexander, Feminist Journalist and Activist
description: She was a reporter, executive director of the National Organization for Women and owner of the restaurant Mother Courage, which became a hub for women.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: He Was Handcuffed and Hospitalized. Now He’s on Track for Housing.
description: A contentious New York City policy to send more mentally ill homeless people to hospitals has helped some move into permanent homes.
content: On the coldest night of the winter, Mazou Mounkaila was sleeping under an overpass in the Bronx when the ambulance crew arrived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jody García and Simon Romero
title: Guatemala Voters Cast Ballots in Contentious Election
description: The election in the Central American nation is marked by the exclusion of top candidates and calls to crack down on violent crime.
content: Voters in Guatemala, the most populous nation in Central America, cast ballots on Sunday in presidential elections that are drawing attention to what many observers called the erosion of the rule of law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: Blinken Says Wagner Rebellion Shows the Cracks in Putin’s Power
description: A brief revolt by the leader of the Wagner mercenary group was a challenge to the authority of President Vladimir Putin of Russia, the secretary of state said during TV appearances on Sunday.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Sunday that the brief rebellion led by the head of the Wagner Group, Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, revealed cracks emerging in President Vladimir V. Putin’s hold on power and cast doubt on the future of his war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: Jury in Pittsburgh Synagogue Trial to Begin Weighing Death Penalty
description: Over the next several weeks, lawyers for Robert Bowers will try to persuade the jury that convicted him to spare his life.
content: This week the real trial begins for Robert Bowers, the man who killed 11 worshipers in a Pittsburgh synagogue on Oct. 27, 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Revolt Raises Searing Question: Could Putin Lose Power?
description: Russians with ties to the Kremlin expressed relief that the mercenary leader’s mutiny did not spark a civil war. But they agreed that Vladimir Putin had come off looking weak in a way that could be lasting.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin long styled himself as Russia’s guarantor of stability and the uncompromising protector of its statehood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Here’s a Look at the Water Crises That Might Be Coming to You Soon
description: Bangladesh, a river delta nation, is on the front line of climate change. Its coping strategies could offer lessons for the wider world.
content: Bangladesh is a land of water. Its silty rivers rush down from the Himalayas, spill into a filigreed maze of ponds, wetlands and tributaries before emptying into the blustery, black Bay of Bengal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman
title: As Legal Fees Mount, Trump Steers Donations Into PAC That Has Covered Them
description: A previously unnoticed change in Donald Trump’s online fund-raising appeals allows him to divert a sizable chunk of his 2024 contributions to a group that has spent millions to cover his legal fees.
content: Facing multiple intensifying investigations, former President Donald J. Trump has quietly begun diverting more of the money he is raising away from his 2024 presidential campaign and into a political action committee that he has used to pay his personal legal fees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Montgomery and Maria Jimenez Moya
title: In Texas, Heat That Can Make You Faint
description: Soaring temperatures above 100 degrees are expected to linger across much of the state well into the coming week.
content: Kevin Randal, a construction worker in Houston, has his routine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka and Matt Twomey
title: Storms Strike Indiana, Killing at Least 1
description: An official in Martin County, Ind., said that one person died and another was injured, but that rescuers were continuing to search for victims.
content: At least one person was killed and another injured as high winds tore apart structures and tennis-ball-sized hail lashed counties south of Indianapolis, where at least one tornado was likely, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: ‘Everybody in the N.F.L. Understands That It’s a Violent Game’
description: Luke Kuechly retired from the N.F.L. while at his peak and has worked to raise awareness of brain trauma. The former linebacker discussed his love for football and what he tells parents of the 12-year-olds he coaches.
content: When Luke Kuechly retired from the N.F.L. in 2020 at 28, he had played eight stellar years as a linebacker for the Carolina Panthers and had sustained at least three documented concussions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Youngblood Gregory
title: What Financial Planning Looks Like for L.G.B.T.Q. People
description: The cost of family planning and transition care — and other personal finance stories from L.G.B.T.Q. people.
content: I married my wife last October in a backyard wedding that my parents hosted and covered for $5,000. My wife’s mother gave us an equivalent honeymoon fund to fly us to France, and our guests were also generous, giving us — to our surprise — a few thousand dollars to start our new lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eli Saslow and Erin Schaff
title: He Tried to Save a Friend. They Charged Him With Murder.
description: They bought $30 worth of fentanyl before making it into rehab. One overdosed. The other was charged in his death.
content: Josh Askins woke up in the crawl space of an abandoned house with nausea, chills and a shooting pain in his legs. It had been seven hours since he last smoked fentanyl, and already he could feel his withdrawal symptoms worsening by the minute. He rolled over in his sleeping bag and stared at the graffiti he’d carved into the rotting floorboards. “Fentanyl is HELL,” he had written a few weeks earlier, but now he got up to start looking for more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Chang Chien
title: Taiwan Faces a #MeToo Wave, Set Off by a Netflix Hit
description: A torrent of sexual harassment accusations has prompted questions about the state of women’s rights on an island democracy that has long been one of Asia’s most progressive places.
content: In the past few weeks, a wave of #MeToo allegations has raced to the very top of Taiwan’s political, judicial and arts scenes, forcing a new reckoning of the state of women’s rights on a democratic island that has long taken pride in being among Asia’s most progressive places.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gardner and Maansi Srivastava
title: Thompson Twins Are Ready for the N.B.A., but Not to Split Up
description: Amen and Ausar Thompson said they’ve never spent more than two days apart. This is how they spent their last week together before heading to their new N.B.A. teams.
content: Amen Thompson and his twin brother, Ausar, sat side by side amid a swirl of tourists at Carmine’s restaurant in Times Square on Monday around 8 p.m. They had flown into New York that morning for the N.B.A. draft at Barclays Center, and now they were trying to decide what dishes to share with their family. Their father, Troy, who is also their agent, ordered sautéed chicken, spaghetti with shrimp and a Caesar salad with anchovies on the side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chantel Tattoli
title: How Far Would You Go for Midcentury Furniture?
description: The owners of Lanoba, a shop that specializes in Danish modern design, find most pieces by going door to door.
content: The credenza in the back of the Mercedes-Benz Sprinter van groaned as Lars Balderskilde drove through the woodlands near Vejle, a city on a fjord about two and a half hours from Copenhagen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naomi Huffman
title: For Natalia Ginzburg, ‘The Road to the City’ Was Strewn With Hurdles
description: The Italian writer’s first book, a novella originally published in 1942, establishes the themes — including thwarted desire and the challenges of family life — for which she became known.
content: What a ridiculous undertaking adolescence is, that span of years when one is bulldozed by uncontrollable and unknowable chemical spasms, when the past is deemed useless and discarded immediately, and the future — whatever that is — is the only thing that matters. One races toward it blindly, with the emotional sensitivity of a cannonball, while simultaneously being forced to decide, ingloriously, prematurely, who to be. It’s good not to take adolescence too seriously, but is there any other way to take it?
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘His Friends Joined In Excitedly and Filmed the Encounter’
description: A birthday on the 1 train, a terrific coat stands out and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: Becoming ‘Self-Made’ Stars in a Secular Age
description: In a breezy new history of personal branding, Tara Isabella Burton comes face to face with Oscar Wilde, Frederick Douglass, Kim Kardashian and more.
content: The Kardashians have sold so much to America — shapewear, cosmetics, beverage upon beverage — why not throw ideas onto the pile?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Are Biofuels Bad for the Environment?
description: Responses to an essay warning against the environmental and humanitarian risks of farm-grown fuels. Also: Single-payer health care; whitewashing history.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Rita Reif, Antiques and Auctions Columnist, Dies at 94
description: She worked at The Times for decades, and she made news herself when she challenged ownership of a painting thought to have been looted by the Nazis.
content: Rita Reif, who after starting out in some of journalism’s lowest-rung jobs spent decades covering the worlds of antiques and auctions for The New York Times, and made news herself in the late 1990s when she challenged the ownership of an Egon Schiele painting thought to have been stolen from a relative of her late husband by the Nazis, died on June 16 in Washington. She was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Don Harold, Sneaky Subway Preservationist, Dies at 91
description: He played an essential role in the creation of the New York Transit Museum by helping to save vintage train cars — sometimes using subterfuge.
content: Don Harold, a subway aficionado who sometimes used subterfuge to save vintage train cars from the junkyard — cars that are now among the star attractions of the New York Transit Museum in Downtown Brooklyn — died on June 14 in a nursing home in Bayside, Queens. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. Hershey Jr
title: Harry Markowitz, Nobel-Winning Pioneer of Modern Portfolio Theory, Dies at 95
description: He overturned the traditional approach to buying stocks by examining the relationship between risk and reward.
content: Harry M. Markowitz, an economist who launched a revolution in finance, upending traditional thinking about buying stocks and earning the Nobel in economic science in 1990 for his breakthrough, died on Thursday in San Diego. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Hollywood Tycoon Testifies in Netanyahu’s Corruption Trial
description: Arnon Milchan, a movie mogul, billionaire spy and old friend of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, is a key witness. He gave the Netanyahus gifts, he said, sometimes at their request.
content: In one of the more dramatic moments in the yearslong corruption trial of Benjamin Netanyahu, Arnon Milchan, a Hollywood movie mogul, billionaire spy and old friend of the Israeli prime minister, took the stand on Sunday as a key witness for the prosecution in an alleged gifts-for-favors affair known as Case 1000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope Offers Prayers for ‘Vatican Girl’ Who Disappeared 40 Years Ago
description: Francis expressed “closeness” to the family of Emanuela Orlandi, whose disappearance has captivated Italians for decades — and now the world, thanks to Netflix.
content: Pope Francis on Sunday marked the 40th anniversary of the kidnapping of Emanuela Orlandi, the 15-year-old daughter of a Vatican employee whose disappearance remains one of Italy’s most enduring mysteries and recently was the subject of a Netflix series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Jenna Lyons, Unlikely Housewife
description: The famously stylish former president of J. Crew has joined the rebooted “Real Housewives of New York City.” Why?
content: Here is how it happened: Jenna Lyons was at the Wing in SoHo in December 2021, giving an interview to a podcast called “Dyking Out,” having recently been advised that she wasn’t doing enough to represent her community of gay women.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 25, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, June 25, 2023.
content: An article on Page 6 this weekend about an immersive “The Great Gatsby” theatrical performance misstates how the character Jay Gatsby comes to an end. He is found dead in a pool, where he has been shot, not drowned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: With Resounding Win in Greece, Kyriakos Mitsotakis Tightens Grip on Power
description: His party’s election victory comes as the country experiences strong economic growth, with voters seemingly willing to look past scandals and disasters that have tarnished his government.
content: Greek voters on Sunday overwhelmingly re-elected the conservative New Democracy party, preliminary results showed, setting the stage for its leader, Kyriakos Mitsotakis, to strengthen his grip on power with an absolute majority and what he called a “strong mandate” for the foreseeable future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leigh Haber
title: New England Island Life Meets Spy Thriller? Look No Further.
description: In “The Beach at Summerly,” Beatriz Williams weaves two standbys of summer fiction into one escapist story.
content: There are moments when busy bibliophiles on holiday want to use precious downtime to bury their Coppertoned noses in a novel designed to be read poolside. These books might conjure memories of summers past: romances that flourished under the hot sun but cooled with autumn’s onset, a state of innocence that didn’t yet connect recklessness with consequences, the bittersweet awareness that summer invariably passes in the flash of a lightning bug.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Oppenheimer
title: The Pittsburgh Gunman Didn’t Just Kill 11 Jews. He Killed a Minyan.
description: Jews need 10 Jews to pray. When one of the 10 is killed, our religious practice is radically altered.
content: During the trial of Robert Bowers, who was convicted of the 2018 murders of 11 Jews in Pittsburgh at the Tree of Life Congregation, I kept thinking about the testimony of Stephen Weiss. Mr. Weiss, a retired public school science teacher and long time ritual director for Tree of Life, was one of the 11 people who survived the attack. During the trial, he told the court that in the years since the event, “We don’t have the same attendance.” He explained that the synagogue lost members who could be counted on to make the minyan, the essential quorum of 10 Jews required for certain prayers. “They were killed.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lazaro Gamio, Marco Hernandez, Josh Holder, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Christine Zhang
